verses.sanskrit: brāhmaṇa-kṣatriya-viśāṃ śūdrāṇāṃ ca parantapa | karmāṇi pravibhaktāni svabhāva-prabhavair guṇaiḥ ||
verses.transliteration: brāhmaṇa-kṣatriya-viśāṃ śūdrāṇāṃ ca parantapa | karmāṇi pravibhaktāni svabhāva-prabhavair guṇaiḥ ||
verses.translation: The duties of brāhmaṇas, kṣatriyas, vaiśyas, and śūdras, O Scorcher of Foes (parantapa), are assigned and distributed (pravibhaktāni) according to the guṇas born of their inherent nature (svabhāva-prabhavaiḥ guṇaiḥ).

word_breakdown.meaning: O Scorcher of Foes (epithet of Arjuna)
born from one's own inherent nature

commentary.dadaji: Krishna grounds the entire four-fold order of society not in birth or heredity but in svabhāva — one's own inner nature as shaped by the three guṇas. 'Svabhāva-prabhavaiḥ guṇaiḥ' means: by the guṇas that arise from one's own constitution. This is a profoundly liberating teaching: your dharma is not an external imposition but an expression of who you already are. The system is descriptive before it is prescriptive. Every being finds their highest fulfillment by acting in accord with the guṇic mix that constitutes their actual nature, for that is the path of least friction and greatest offering to God.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse opens the varṇa-dharma section with a crucial philosophical statement. The four-fold division of duties is not arbitrary social engineering — it reflects the natural distribution of the three guṇas in human beings. 'Pravibhaktāni' (distinctly divided) suggests that these duties are already present in nature itself; society only recognizes and formalizes what svabhāva has already determined. Swami Vivekananda's reading is relevant: one's real caste is determined by one's qualities and actions (guṇa-karma), not by the accident of birth. Krishna addresses Arjuna as 'parantapa' — reminding the warrior that he himself is the very embodiment of kṣatriya svabhāva.
commentary.yogananda: The Divine Architect has built variety into creation. Each soul comes equipped with a particular blend of sattva, rajas, and tamas that predisposes it toward certain kinds of work and service. This cosmic design ensures that all necessary functions of civilization are fulfilled — contemplation, protection, production, and service — by those who are inwardly fitted for them. The error of misidentifying one's svabhāva — forcing oneself into a role that does not match one's inner constitution — leads to spiritual frustration and social disorder. When each person works from their authentic inner nature, every task becomes a path back to God.
commentary.goyandka: The Lord here declares that the four-fold division of duties among brāhmaṇas, kṣatriyas, vaiśyas, and śūdras is not arbitrary but is rooted in the guṇas that naturally arise from each person's svabhāva. This svabhāva is the accumulated result of past tendencies (saṃskāras) and karmas carried across lifetimes. One should therefore discern one's own svabhāva honestly and perform the duties appropriate to it, for that alone is true dharma. The word 'pravibhaktāni' assures us that these distinctions are real and meaningful, not mere social conventions to be discarded lightly.

verses.sanskrit: śamo damas tapaḥ śaucaṃ kṣāntir ārjavam eva ca | jñānaṃ vijñānam āstikyaṃ brahma-karma svabhāva-jam ||
verses.transliteration: śamo damas tapaḥ śaucaṃ kṣāntir ārjavam eva ca | jñānaṃ vijñānam āstikyaṃ brahma-karma svabhāva-jam ||
verses.translation: Serenity (śama), self-restraint (dama), austerity (tapaḥ), purity (śauca), forgiveness (kṣānti), uprightness (ārjava), knowledge (jñāna), experiential wisdom (vijñāna), and faith in the divine (āstikya) — these are the brāhmaṇa's duties, born of svabhāva.

word_breakdown.meaning: faith in the Vedas, in God, in the next world

commentary.dadaji: Nine luminous qualities constitute the brāhmaṇa's vocation — all of them sattvic, all of them inward. Notice that 'jñāna' and 'vijñāna' appear together: theoretical knowledge and direct experiential realization. The brāhmaṇa is not merely a scholar but a knower — one whose life is a living transmission of the sacred. 'Āstikya' — faith — is placed last as the crown: faith in the Vedas, in karma, in the divine order, in liberation. These nine qualities are not merely professional duties; they are modes of being that purify both the person who embodies them and the world that comes into contact with them. The brāhmaṇa's highest service is the radiation of sattva.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The brāhmaṇa's dharma is essentially the contemplative life in its fullest expression. 'Śama' and 'dama' — the twin pillars of mental and sensory control — appear first because without them, no genuine knowledge is possible. 'Tapaḥ' here means the patient, disciplined burning away of impurities through sustained practice. The distinction between 'jñāna' and 'vijñāna' is philosophically critical: jñāna is knowledge about the Self and reality; vijñāna is the direct knowing of that reality in one's own immediate experience. The Vedāntic tradition consistently upholds vijñāna as the superior and culminating form of knowledge. Āstikya — deep faith — is the foundation upon which the entire spiritual edifice rests.
commentary.yogananda: These nine qualities represent the ideal spiritual nature that the brāhmaṇa is called to embody and transmit. Serenity of mind (śama) is the inner garden in which divine knowledge can bloom. Self-restraint (dama) guards the senses from scattering the spiritual energy outward. Austerity (tapas) means the willingness to endure discomfort for the sake of higher realization. Together, jñāna and vijñāna form the complete arc from reading about God to knowing God directly. The true brāhmaṇa, regardless of birth, is one in whom these nine fires burn steadily — purifying not only themselves but all who come near them.
commentary.goyandka: These nine qualities define the brāhmaṇa's svabhāva-dharma. The emphasis falls on inner discipline: śama (subduing the mind) and dama (subduing the senses) are prerequisites for all the rest. Purity (śauca) includes both outer cleanliness and inner freedom from desire and hatred. Āstikya — belief in the validity of the Vedas and the reality of the ātman's journey — is the spiritual foundation without which all outward learning becomes hollow scholarship. The brāhmaṇa's supreme duty is to preserve, embody, and transmit this living wisdom from generation to generation, maintaining the sacred fire of dharmic knowledge in the world.

verses.sanskrit: śauryaṃ tejo dhṛtir dākṣyaṃ yuddhe cāpy apalāyanam | dānam īśvara-bhāvaś ca kṣātraṃ karma svabhāva-jam ||
verses.transliteration: śauryaṃ tejo dhṛtir dākṣyaṃ yuddhe cāpy apalāyanam | dānam īśvara-bhāvaś ca kṣātraṃ karma svabhāva-jam ||
verses.translation: Heroism (śauryam), vigor (tejas), steadfastness (dhṛti), skillfulness (dākṣya), not fleeing in battle (apalāyanam), generosity (dānam), and lordly bearing (īśvara-bhāvaḥ) — these are the kṣatriya's natural duties, born of svabhāva.

commentary.dadaji: Seven qualities constitute the kṣatriya's dharma — all expressions of rajas refined by righteousness in service of protection. 'Apalāyanam' — not fleeing from battle — strikes with particular force here, given that Arjuna's entire crisis began with his impulse to flee. Krishna is not merely listing abstract virtues; he is holding up a mirror to Arjuna's own svabhāva and asking: is this not who you are? 'Īśvara-bhāva' — the bearing of a ruler — means the natural quality of assuming responsibility, of caring for those under one's protection. The kṣatriya's rajas is not aggression but protection: the fierce love of a guardian who will not abandon those who depend on them.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The kṣatriya's dharma is rajas expressed in its most noble and socially necessary form. Note that 'dānam' (generosity) appears alongside martial qualities — the warrior is not merely a fighter but a protector and provider, someone who gives as well as guards. 'Tejas' here carries a double meaning: the physical vigor of a trained warrior and the inner luminosity that comes from living one's svabhāva completely. 'Īśvara-bhāva' — the quality of a ruler — is a natural expression of someone in whom the protecting, ordering, and guiding functions are naturally dominant. This is not arrogance but the natural assumption of responsibility that comes with being constituted for leadership.
commentary.yogananda: The kṣatriya is the embodiment of divine will in action — protecting the innocent, upholding justice, facing evil without flinching. These seven qualities describe a soul in whom God's protective power is especially concentrated. 'Apalāyanam' — not fleeing — is both physical courage in battle and the deeper spiritual courage to face one's own karma and duty without evasion. 'Tejas' is the divine fire that burns in such a soul: the warrior's aura that commands respect not through domination but through authentic strength. The gift of 'dānam' shows that true kṣatriya power is never merely for self-preservation but is always in service of a larger protection.
commentary.goyandka: The Lord here enumerates the seven natural qualities of the kṣatriya whose svabhāva is dominated by rajas tempered with dharma. 'Dhṛti' — steadfastness — is especially important: the warrior must not be swayed by momentary fear or sentiment from performing the duty of protection. 'Dākṣya' (skillfulness) shows that mastery of one's craft — whether it be archery, statecraft, or military strategy — is itself a dharmic duty for the kṣatriya. The combination of courage, skill, generosity, and leadership creates the ideal ruler-warrior whose life is a protection and blessing to society. Arjuna himself possesses all these qualities; Krishna's purpose is to awaken him to his own svabhāva.

verses.sanskrit: kṛṣi-go-rakṣya-vāṇijyaṃ vaiśya-karma svabhāva-jam | paricaryātmakaṃ karma śūdrasyāpi svabhāva-jam ||
verses.transliteration: kṛṣi-go-rakṣya-vāṇijyaṃ vaiśya-karma svabhāva-jam | paricaryātmakaṃ karma śūdrasyāpi svabhāva-jam ||
verses.translation: Agriculture (kṛṣi), cattle-rearing (go-rakṣya), and trade (vāṇijyam) — these are the vaiśya's natural duties, born of svabhāva; service (paricarya) is also (api) the natural duty of the śūdra, born of svabhāva.

word_breakdown.meaning: of the nature of service, consisting in service

commentary.dadaji: The word 'api' — 'also' or 'even' — in the second half of this verse is full of grace. Even the śūdra's service is svabhāva-jam — born from their own nature, sacred and divinely ordered. No function in the social organism is degraded when performed as one's genuine svabhāva-dharma with devotion to God. The vaiśya's three duties — farming, animal husbandry, and commerce — sustain the material life of civilization. These are not lesser vocations; they are the activities by which the earth feeds humanity and the economy functions. Every seed sown with consciousness is an act of worship; every honest trade is a yajña.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse covers both the vaiśya and the śūdra in one compact statement, with the critical word 'api' (also/even) asserting that the śūdra's svabhāva-jam service is equally dharmic and equally honorable. The three vaiśya duties — kṛṣi, go-rakṣya, vāṇijya — represent the sustaining functions of civilization: food production, livestock care, and economic exchange. The śūdra's paricaryā encompasses skilled labor, craftsmanship, and all forms of service that support the other three functions. The Gītā's vision is of an integrated, interdependent social organism where every function is necessary and every svabhāva-based vocation is a path toward God.
commentary.yogananda: God is as present in the farmer's field as in the philosopher's study. The vaiśya who tends cattle and conducts honest commerce, and the śūdra who renders skilled service — both are performing divinely ordained functions that sustain the world. The word 'api' (also/even) in relation to the śūdra carries a liberating message: no sincere form of service is spiritually inferior. What elevates any work to the sacred is not its social prestige but the quality of consciousness — the bhāva — with which it is offered. Every worker, regardless of vocation, can make their daily labor into a continuous act of worship by dedicating it to the divine.
commentary.goyandka: The Lord here completes the description of all four svabhāva-dharmas. The vaiśya's three duties — agriculture, cow protection, and commerce — sustain the material foundation upon which the entire society rests. Cow protection (go-rakṣya) is mentioned specifically as it represents not only an economic activity but a sacred duty in the Vedic understanding. For the śūdra, 'paricaryātmakam karma' — action consisting in service — includes all forms of skilled support, craftsmanship, and labor. The use of 'api' (also/even) is significant: even the śūdra's duty is svabhāva-jam — naturally born and spiritually valid. One should never belittle any dharma performed with sincerity and devotion.

verses.sanskrit: sve sve karmaṇy abhirataḥ saṃsiddhiṃ labhate naraḥ | sva-karma-nirataḥ siddhiṃ yathā vindati tac chṛṇu ||
verses.transliteration: sve sve karmaṇy abhirataḥ saṃsiddhiṃ labhate naraḥ | sva-karma-nirataḥ siddhiṃ yathā vindati tac chṛṇu ||
verses.translation: Devoted to and delighting in (abhirataḥ) one's own proper duty (sve sve karmaṇi), a person (naraḥ) attains supreme perfection (saṃsiddhim). How one devoted to one's own duty (sva-karma-nirataḥ) finds that perfection (siddhim) — hear that from Me.

word_breakdown.meaning: in one's very own duty (emphatic repetition)
devoted to, delighting in, absorbed in
devoted and engaged in one's own duty

commentary.dadaji: The double repetition — 'sve sve karmaṇi' (in one's very own duty) and the pairing of 'saṃsiddhim labhate' with 'siddhim vindati' — creates a deliberate emphasis: this teaching is universal. Every person, in every vocation, doing their own dharma with genuine devotion (abhirataḥ — delighting in it), can attain the supreme perfection of liberation. 'Abhirata' is particularly beautiful: it is not mere compliance but delight, absorption, love for one's own work. The upcoming verse will explain how this is possible — through the act of dedicating one's work as worship to the divine source of all activity.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This pivotal verse announces the universal applicability of the karma yoga path. 'Sve sve' — one's very own — is an emphatic repetition that underscores the necessity of authenticity. You must find and do your own dharma, not someone else's. 'Abhirata' goes beyond mere performance: it implies a joyful absorption, a natural aptitude and love for the work. When one's work flows from genuine svabhāva, it is energizing rather than draining, fulfilling rather than alienating. 'Saṃsiddhi' — supreme perfection — is the goal: not just worldly success but the ultimate liberation. The next verse will provide the mechanism: offering one's work as worship.
commentary.yogananda: This verse is one of the great promises of the Gītā: no one is excluded from the path to God on account of their social function or vocation. The farmer, the merchant, the scholar, the soldier — all can attain liberation by doing their own work with devotion and joy. 'Abhirata' — delighting in — is the key: when your work arises from your authentic svabhāva, it becomes a source of spiritual energy rather than a burden. God has distributed the divine light not only through contemplatives but through every sincere worker who offers their labor as an act of love. The following verse reveals the transforming principle: sva-karmaṇā tam abhyarcya — worshipping God through one's own work.
commentary.goyandka: The Lord here makes a sweeping and compassionate declaration: any person who is genuinely devoted to their own svabhāva-dharma — not reluctantly, but with true absorption (abhirataḥ) — attains the supreme perfection of liberation. This is the practical heart of the Gītā's social teaching. The system of varṇa-dharma is not meant to confine or oppress but to liberate: by directing each person toward the work most suited to their inner nature, it transforms daily labor into a spiritual path. 'Sva-karma-nirataḥ' — one who is wholly committed to their own duty — does not need to abandon the world to find God; the path to God runs directly through their own authentic work.

verses.sanskrit: yataḥ pravṛttir bhūtānāṃ yena sarvam idaṃ tatam | sva-karmaṇā tam abhyarcya siddhiṃ vindati mānavaḥ ||
verses.transliteration: yataḥ pravṛttir bhūtānāṃ yena sarvam idaṃ tatam | sva-karmaṇā tam abhyarcya siddhiṃ vindati mānavaḥ ||
verses.translation: From whom all beings have their activity (pravṛtti), by whom all this is pervaded (sarvam idam tatam) — by worshipping That One (tam abhyarcya) through one's own proper duty (sva-karmaṇā) — a person (mānavaḥ) attains perfection (siddhim).

word_breakdown.meaning: by one's own duty, through one's own action

commentary.dadaji: This is the practical mechanism that transforms all work into worship: 'sva-karmaṇā tam abhyarcya' — worshipping the Lord through one's own duty. The Lord is described in two cosmic terms: the source from whom all beings draw their activity (pravṛtti), and the one by whom all this universe is pervaded (tatam). By recognizing your own work as an act in the divine drama — as the Lord's own activity flowing through you — every gesture of your dharma becomes an offering. The carpenter who offers their craft to God, the mother who offers her care to God, the farmer who offers their harvest to God — all attain the same perfection as the renunciant sitting in meditation.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse contains one of the most profound teachings of the entire Gītā. 'Sva-karmaṇā tam abhyarcya' — by worshipping That through one's own duty — is the complete karma yoga formula in four words. The Lord is identified here in the most universal terms: the source of all activity in all beings, and the one who pervades all existence. When you recognize this pervasiveness and perform your daily duty as an act of worship to this all-pervading presence, your work is transformed. It becomes yajña — sacred offering. No monastery is needed; no special ritual is required. Your workplace becomes a temple, your daily tasks become liturgy, and your sincere effort becomes prayer.
commentary.yogananda: God, as the verse declares, is the source from which all beings draw their very capacity for action — 'yataḥ pravṛttir bhūtānām.' Every time you act, you are channeling a power that originates in the divine. To worship God through one's own duty (sva-karmaṇā tam abhyarcya) is to consciously restore that acknowledgment — to act with the awareness that you are an instrument of the divine will, that your work is God working through you. This transforms even the most mundane activity into a spiritual practice. When this consciousness is sustained, perfection (siddhi) follows naturally, because one's entire life has become an unbroken act of devotion.
commentary.goyandka: The key phrase is 'sva-karmaṇā tam abhyarcya' — by worshipping the Lord through one's own duty. The Lord is described here as both the source of all activity (pravṛtti) and the all-pervasive ground of all existence (sarvam idam tatam). This means that your own work takes place within the divine being, is powered by the divine energy, and can be consciously offered back to the divine source. There is no separation between sacred and secular when this recognition dawns. Every field that is plowed, every student that is taught, every dispute that is resolved justly — all become acts of worship to the Lord who pervades all things.

verses.sanskrit: śreyān sva-dharmo viguṇaḥ para-dharmāt sv-anuṣṭhitāt | svabhāva-niyataṃ karma kurvan nāpnoti kilbiṣam ||
verses.transliteration: śreyān sva-dharmo viguṇaḥ para-dharmāt sv-anuṣṭhitāt | svabhāva-niyataṃ karma kurvan nāpnoti kilbiṣam ||
verses.translation: Better (śreyān) is one's own dharma, even if imperfectly performed (viguṇaḥ), than the dharma of another, even if well performed (sv-anuṣṭhitāt). Performing the action ordained by one's own nature (svabhāva-niyatam karma), one does not incur sin (kilbiṣam).

word_breakdown.meaning: one's own dharma, one's proper duty
regulated and ordained by one's own nature
does not incur, does not obtain

commentary.dadaji: This verse, which echoes Chapter 3 verse 35, is one of the most compassionate teachings in all of scripture. 'Viguṇaḥ' — imperfect, without all the proper qualities — means: even if you cannot perform your sva-dharma perfectly, even if you stumble, even if you lack every quality it requires, it is still better than doing someone else's dharma perfectly. You are not expected to be someone else. You are expected to be your best self — authentic, sincere, growing. 'Svabhāva-niyatam karma kurvan nāpnoti kilbiṣam' — performing action regulated by one's own nature, one accumulates no sin. Authenticity to your own soul is its own protection.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The restatement of this principle from Chapter 3 here in Chapter 18 signals its absolute centrality in the Gītā's ethical framework. 'Śreyān sva-dharmo viguṇaḥ' — better one's own imperfect dharma. The word 'viguṇaḥ' is striking: it literally means 'without all the guṇas/qualities' — acknowledging that no one performs their dharma with perfect excellence. Imperfect authenticity beats perfect inauthenticity. 'Para-dharma' — another's dharma — can seem attractive, more prestigious, more effective; but it is borrowed and ultimately alienating. The protection promised in the second line — 'nāpnoti kilbiṣam' (incurs no sin) — is a profound reassurance: when you act from your genuine svabhāva, the cosmic order supports you.
commentary.yogananda: God does not ask you to be anyone other than yourself. This is the liberating message of this verse. Your own dharma, rooted in your authentic svabhāva, even when performed imperfectly — with stumbling and learning and occasional failure — is of greater spiritual worth than a brilliant performance of a dharma that does not belong to you. Imitation may appear successful outwardly but creates inner spiritual conflict. Authenticity, even with its imperfections, creates inner harmony and, ultimately, liberation. 'Nāpnoti kilbiṣam' — one incurs no sin — because when action flows from one's genuine nature in service of the divine, it carries the protection of that alignment.
commentary.goyandka: This verse is a direct restatement of the teaching given in Chapter 3 verse 35, here in the culminating chapter of the Gītā. Its repetition emphasizes its supreme importance. The word 'viguṇaḥ' acknowledges realistically that no one performs their sva-dharma with complete perfection — all human action has some limitation. But even this imperfect performance of authentic dharma is superior to the seemingly flawless performance of an alien dharma. 'Svabhāva-niyatam karma' — action regulated by one's own deepest nature — is karma that carries no binding sin (kilbiṣa), because it flows from the truth of one's being rather than from pretension, imitation, or anxiety.

verses.sanskrit: saha-jaṃ karma kaunteya sa-doṣam api na tyajet | sarvārambhā hi doṣeṇa dhūmenāgnir ivāvṛtāḥ ||
verses.transliteration: saha-jaṃ karma kaunteya sa-doṣam api na tyajet | sarvārambhā hi doṣeṇa dhūmenāgnir ivāvṛtāḥ ||
verses.translation: Obligatory duty born together with oneself (saha-jaṃ karma), O Kaunteya, should not be abandoned even if it is flawed (sa-doṣam api). For all undertakings are enveloped by faults (doṣeṇa āvṛtāḥ) as fire is by smoke (dhūmenāgniḥ iva).

word_breakdown.meaning: born together with oneself, congenital, innate
even if possessing faults, even if imperfect
should not abandon, must not give up

commentary.dadaji: The fire-and-smoke simile is one of the most practical teachings in the Gītā. Every fire produces smoke — that is the nature of fire in the world. To wait for a fire without smoke is to wait forever. Similarly, every action — every undertaking of any kind — carries some flaw, some incompleteness, some unintended consequence. To use the inevitability of imperfection as a reason for not acting, or for abandoning one's saha-ja karma (the duty born with oneself), is a subtle form of spiritual evasion. Act from your svabhāva, accept the unavoidable smoke, and offer both the flame and the smoke to God. That is the mature spiritual stance.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The word 'saha-jam' — born together with oneself — deepens our understanding of svabhāva-dharma. This is not an externally assigned role but a duty that is as intimate as your own breath, born with your very body and constitution. 'Sa-doṣam api na tyajet' — even if flawed, do not abandon it. The pragmatic wisdom of the fire-smoke simile is striking: Krishna is not promising a perfect, blame-free action. He is acknowledging the real-world complexity of action and asking for commitment despite it. Perfectionism — the refusal to act until one can act perfectly — is itself a form of adharma, a failure of duty. Act, accept the limitation, offer the result, grow.
commentary.yogananda: The ancient wisdom of this verse addresses a very human tendency: to abandon one's dharma because it seems too imperfect, too difficult, too flawed. Krishna answers with natural realism: fire always comes with smoke. The greater the fire, the more it produces both light and smoke. The warrior who is truly fighting for justice will inevitably make some mistakes. The farmer tilling the earth will inevitably disturb some small creatures. The teacher will sometimes give imperfect instruction. These unavoidable flaws are the 'smoke' of the fire of action — they cannot be entirely avoided, and they should not be allowed to extinguish the fire of one's duty.
commentary.goyandka: The Lord here addresses the temptation to abandon one's saha-ja karma — duty born with oneself — because it appears flawed or imperfect. This temptation must be firmly resisted. 'Sarvārambhā hi doṣeṇa dhūmenāgnir ivāvṛtāḥ' — all undertakings are indeed enveloped by faults as fire is by smoke. This is the nature of action in the material world; it cannot be otherwise. The key is not to achieve a faultless action (which is impossible) but to perform one's saha-ja karma with sincerity, non-attachment, and dedication to God. The unavoidable imperfections do not produce binding karma when the work is offered as worship.

verses.sanskrit: asakta-buddhiḥ sarvatra jitātmā vigata-spṛhaḥ | naiṣkarmya-siddhiṃ paramāṃ sannyāsenādhigacchati ||
verses.transliteration: asakta-buddhiḥ sarvatra jitātmā vigata-spṛhaḥ | naiṣkarmya-siddhiṃ paramāṃ sannyāsenādhigacchati ||
verses.translation: The person of unattached intelligence (asakta-buddhiḥ) everywhere, the self-conquered (jitātmā), the desire-free (vigata-spṛhaḥ) — through renunciation (sannyāsena) attains the supreme state of freedom from action (naiṣkarmya-siddhim paramām).

word_breakdown.meaning: one whose intelligence is unattached, non-clinging
one who has conquered the self, self-subdued
one from whom desire has departed, desire-free
the perfection of actionlessness, freedom from karmic bondage

commentary.dadaji: 'Naiṣkarmya-siddhi' — the perfection of actionlessness — is not physical passivity but the inner state in which action leaves no karmic trace because the ego-doer is absent. 'Asakta-buddhi sarvatra' — intelligence unattached everywhere — means that whether in pleasure or pain, success or failure, the intelligence does not cling to any experience. 'Jitātmā' — the self-conquered — has overcome the lower self's habitual identification with body and ego. 'Vigata-spṛha' — desire has entirely departed. 'Sannyāsena' here is inner renunciation — the tyāga that has been discussed throughout this chapter — not merely wearing the robes of a monk. This is the state from which one naturally rises to Brahman.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse describes the inner condition that produces naiṣkarmya-siddhi — freedom from the binding power of action. Three qualities define this person: asakta-buddhi (intelligence that holds on to nothing), jitātmā (the lower self thoroughly conquered), and vigata-spṛha (no remaining desires). 'Sannyāsena' here carries the meaning developed throughout Chapter 18: inner renunciation of the fruit and the doership, not necessarily external monasticism. When these three inner conditions are met, action flows from pure being without accumulating karmic residue. The person acts, but action does not bind them — like a lotus leaf in water, they move through the world without being soaked by it.
commentary.yogananda: The state described here — asakta-buddhi, jitātmā, vigata-spṛha — is the condition of the jivanmukta, the one liberated while still living. Intelligence that does not attach itself anywhere is like a clear mirror that reflects everything but retains nothing. The self-conquered person has mastered the inner battlefield that the entire Gītā addresses. Desire-freedom (vigata-spṛha) does not mean joylessness but the absence of the compulsive craving that creates suffering and karmic entanglement. 'Sannyāsa' here is the inner abandonment of the fruits of all action, combined with the three qualities — and from this inner renunciation, the supreme freedom naturally follows.
commentary.goyandka: 'Naiṣkarmya-siddhi' — the supreme perfection of actionlessness — is the state in which one performs all necessary actions without any binding karmic effect, because the intelligence is not attached (asakta-buddhi) and desires are entirely gone (vigata-spṛha). This is not achieved by abandoning external action but by the inner transformation described by these three terms. 'Sannyāsena' — through renunciation — refers to the inner renunciation (tyāga) that the Lord has been describing: the giving up of attachment to results and the sense of doership. The jitātmā — the self-conquered — has subdued all inner enemies and acts purely as an instrument of divine will, accumulating no further karmic debt.

verses.sanskrit: siddhiṃ prāpto yathā brahma tathāpnoti nibodha me | samāsenaiva kaunteya niṣṭhā jñānasya yā parā ||
verses.transliteration: siddhiṃ prāpto yathā brahma tathāpnoti nibodha me | samāsenaiva kaunteya niṣṭhā jñānasya yā parā ||
verses.translation: How one who has attained perfection (siddhiṃ prāptaḥ) then attains Brahman (tathā brahma āpnoti) — hear that from Me briefly (samāsena eva, nibodha me), O Kaunteya — that is the supreme culmination (parā niṣṭhā) of knowledge (jñānasya).

word_breakdown.meaning: hear from Me, understand from Me
which is supreme, which is the highest

commentary.dadaji: This verse is a magnificent threshold — a doorway opening onto the highest teaching. Having described naiṣkarmya-siddhi in verse 49, Krishna now says: but that is not the end. There is something beyond even freedom from action — Brahman itself. 'Siddhiṃ prāptaḥ' — having attained the perfection of verse 49 — 'yathā brahma tathāpnoti' — how one then attains Brahman. The 'samāsena' (briefly) signals that what follows (verses 51-55) will be a concise distillation of the highest jñāna. 'Parā niṣṭhā jñānasya' — the supreme resting place of knowledge — is Brahman itself: the final dissolution of the seeker into the sought.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This transition verse is structurally crucial. It marks the shift from karma yoga perfection (naiṣkarmya-siddhi) to jñāna yoga culmination (brahma-prāpti). 'Parā niṣṭhā jñānasya' — the highest resting place of knowledge — is a beautiful phrase: knowledge does not float endlessly; it comes to rest in Brahman. This is the niṣṭhā — the settling, the final establishment. The verses that follow (51-55) will describe the qualities of the person who has realized Brahman. 'Samāsena' — briefly — is significant: the Absolute cannot be comprehended by elaborate description. Only the most essential pointers can be given. The rest must be experienced directly.
commentary.yogananda: Having guided Arjuna step by step through action, duty, svabhāva, renunciation, and inner freedom, Krishna now points to the final destination: Brahman itself. The perfection achieved through naiṣkarmya-siddhi is itself a kind of threshold — a purified state of being from which the final leap into Brahman becomes possible. 'Parā niṣṭhā jñānasya' — the supreme culmination of knowledge — is not another concept to be added to one's intellectual collection; it is the dissolution of the separate knower into the ocean of pure knowing. Krishna promises to give this teaching 'samāsena' — briefly — because the deepest truths require not more words but fewer, said with greater precision.
commentary.goyandka: This verse serves as a hinge between the practical teaching (svabhāva-dharma, karma yoga) and the ultimate teaching (brahma-prāpti). 'Siddhiṃ prāptaḥ' refers to the naiṣkarmya-siddhi described in verse 49 — the state of one who has thoroughly purified the antaḥkaraṇa (inner instrument) through the practice of non-attached action. From this platform of inner purity, Brahman-realization becomes available. Krishna promises to give this highest teaching 'samāsena' — briefly and essentially — because one who has reached this level of inner preparation needs only the clearest possible pointer, not elaborate elaboration. Verses 51-55 will provide that supreme pointer.
